div1.head: (To women sternly)
div1.p: Do you suppose you have nothing waiting for yourselves to do, but to embroider, to clean, and to be respectable and modest, and to not swear or drink?

lg.l:
That is profitablegreat to you which
you carry with you
after death

I will carefully earn all
the riches which I

lg.head: Poem
lg.l: I will ...

div1.p: All poems, or any other expressions of literature, that do not tally with their writers actual life and knowledge, are lies.

lg.l:
I will make a song that
there is no imperfection
in man or woman

And I will make a
song that there each
thing is no one thing
in the universe is
inferior to another, and
that all are equally
miracles

And I will make a
song that there is
nothing more beautiful
than death.

And I will make a
song that whatever
happens to any one
may become beautiful

And I will make a new
song of riches, namely
the riches of the body
and the spirit, which
are before death
and after death

div1.p: ☞ Every Poem of any thing must enclose and express the spirituality and joy of that thing—(of the train of that thing)—(of these things)—not be a mere didactic

Finally after all the physical greatness of the city is attained—after the architecture of the house is finished—then what is the man in the housecity or What of the woman?— What is a great city or a great house, without great men? great women?

div1.head: Motto for all political philos action
Walt Whitman's terrible Motto.
div1.p: No nation, once fully enslaved, ever fully recovered its liberty.—
—first a respectful word to to those who in all ancient times, and in all times in unknown nations, have written wise words, or taught them—
Wisdom comes mostly back to the projector, teller—no matter if no record—

lg.head: Poem
poem to one three centuries hence or thirty centuries hence
lg.l:
To I, alert,
formedvisible comport, full of
life, thirty-eight
years old,

To you, yet unborn,
these.

Now
As When you read these I that, was
visible am become invisible

Now it is you are compact,
full of life, reading
my my
my these poems,

If I were here doubtlesswith you
it may be we would
love another

div1.p: What would be thought of a surgeon or physician who should be delicate and modest, and treat of costumes and respect the and know only the body as it appears in fashionable costumes?— What is more real than sex? What is there at all the facts of existence but procreation?— Yet Tthese are the very things,—what misses these, misses all. There is just the same reason for my poems, and what they seek to do, to include sex and procreation, as there is for the surg physician to include them

div1.p: the idea of grades in the mental condition and development of people

The people are in strata—remember the vast, largest, most continued popular strata (? strats)—also the various other strata, those of criminals, those of ignorant persons—Also, in other countries, under the religious and governments.— For instance, the common people, what they are, with their physique, their social customs, liberty, slavery, and the rest—
This The great fact of grades comprehendsincludes and explains a hundred subordinated facts; without them it, the included facts not well understood.—

lg.head: ? Poem of the past
lg.l: Poemet

l.del: What in the poem of the Past

lg.l:
I was looking a long while for the poem
of the past and now
I have found it

It is the Present—it is
the this Earth to-day, and
all t Ame this
America, and all
languages and nations

It is the long broad show
of artificial things, ships,
international comme
exchanges, books,
and the interchanges
of nations

del.p: Poem expressing the sentiment of the joy of old age—of an old person—(or in the poem of Joys)

lg.l: O my old age,manhood! my

My children and grandchildren! My white hair and
beard! My calmnesslargenessmajesty
calmness and peacemajesty from
many many years!

lg.l:
O the exquisitenessjoy of
my womanhood!—O ripened
happiness at last!

I am more than seventyeighty
years of age, in perfect health —my

My hair also too is pure white—
I My I am the most
venerable mother in
perfect health —I am complete in myself

To me also all people are
drawn more than
draw nigh—they I f
attract with more than I
the attraction of my youth.—

idea of the avatars,
